articles.headline: China’s Economy Slows, but Inflation Still Looms
articles.snippet: The big question now is how much economic growth may slow, before the authorities shift their priority from controlling inflation to revving the growth engine.
articles.abstract: The big question now is how much economic growth may slow, before the authorities shift their priority from controlling inflation to revving the growth engine.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHANGSHA, China — China’s economy is starting to slow, after two years of torrid growth achieved following the global downturn.

articles.headline: Drug Trade Flourishes in Spanish Port Town
articles.snippet: Amid hard times, drug smuggling has found a revival in Barbate, an area plagued by drug activity because of its proximity to North Africa.
articles.abstract: Amid hard times, drug smuggling has found a revival in Barbate, an area plagued by drug activity because of its proximity to North Africa.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARBATE, SPAIN — In the police station of Barbate, a port town in the southern region of Andalusia, officers have pinned a poster to the wall that reads “they owe us April,” referring to the late payment of their salaries.

articles.headline: Housing Index Is Expected to Show a New Low in Prices
articles.snippet: The downward spiral of the housing market, which experts expect will continue, has not only lowered home ownership, but tarnished a piece of the American dream.
articles.abstract: The downward spiral of the housing market, which experts expect will continue, has not only lowered home ownership, but tarnished a piece of the American dream.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The desire to own your own home, long a bedrock of the American Dream, is fast becoming a casualty of the worst housing downturn since the Great Depression.

articles.headline: In Japan, a Culture That Promotes Nuclear Dependency
articles.snippet: Tokyo has showered generous subsidies, payouts and jobs on local communities that host or expand nuclear power plants.
articles.abstract: Tokyo has showered generous subsidies, payouts and jobs on local communities that host or expand nuclear power plants.
articles.lead_paragraph: KASHIMA, Japan — When the Shimane nuclear plant was first proposed here more than 40 years ago, this rural port town put up such fierce resistance that the plant’s would-be operator, Chugoku Electric, almost scrapped the project. Angry fishermen vowed to defend areas where they had fished and harvested seaweed for generations.
articles.byline: By Martin Fackler and Norimitsu Onishi

articles.headline: Breaches Lead to Push to Protect Medical Data
articles.snippet: The Department of Health and Human Services is using existing rules to enforce medical privacy, but some wonder if stronger laws are needed.
articles.abstract: The Department of Health and Human Services is using existing rules to enforce medical privacy, but some wonder if stronger laws are needed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal health officials call it the Wall of Shame. It’s a government Web page that lists nearly 300 hospitals, doctors and insurance companies that have reported significant breaches of medical privacy in the last couple of years.

articles.headline: Not a Flashy Investor, Just Successful
articles.snippet: Martin Sass runs a boutique investment firm with $8 billion in assets. He doesn’t believe in get-rich-quick schemes and has “a healthy degree of paranoia.”
articles.abstract: Martin Sass runs a boutique investment firm with $8 billion in assets. He doesn’t believe in get-rich-quick schemes and has “a healthy degree of paranoia.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The money manager Martin D. Sass loves a good bargain.

articles.headline: Egypt’s Christians Fear Violence as Changes Embolden Islamists
articles.snippet: A surge of sectarian violence in Cairo has turned Christian-Muslim tensions into one of the gravest threats to the revolution’s stability.
articles.abstract: A surge of sectarian violence in Cairo has turned Christian-Muslim tensions into one of the gravest threats to the revolution’s stability.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The headline screamed from a venerable liberal newspaper: Coptic Christians had abducted a young Muslim and tattooed her with a cross. “Copts kidnap Raghada!”

articles.headline: Pressing Obama, House Bars Rise for Debt Ceiling
articles.snippet: The House overwhelmingly rejected a measure to increase the debt limit, a vote staged by Republicans to pressure President Obama to accept deep cuts.
articles.abstract: The House overwhelmingly rejected a measure to increase the debt limit, a vote staged by Republicans to pressure President Obama to accept deep cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House on Tuesday overwhelmingly rejected a measure to increase the government’s debt limit, acting on a vote staged by Republican leaders to pressure President Obama to agree to deep spending cuts.

articles.headline: Bottom May Be Near for Slide in Housing
articles.snippet: An index of prices in 20 cities is down 33.1 percent from the peak in July 2006 after falling for the eighth straight month in March.
articles.abstract: An index of prices in 20 cities is down 33.1 percent from the peak in July 2006 after falling for the eighth straight month in March.
articles.lead_paragraph: How low can the market go?

articles.headline: A New York Dog Makes Its Hollywood Debut
articles.snippet: Papaya King has landed in Los Angeles, a city that might be as crazy and competitive about food as New York is.
articles.abstract: Papaya King has landed in Los Angeles, a city that might be as crazy and competitive about food as New York is.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD — It is tucked in a storefront a block from the Walk of Fame, walking distance from the annual Academy Awards ceremonies, and steps from the hubbub of tourists, hucksters and celebrity hunters that is Hollywood: a Papaya King hot dog stand, in all its garish yellow and orange glory, selling hot dogs imported straight from the Bronx.

articles.headline: Trichet to Leave a Difficult Legacy at Central Bank
articles.snippet: When Jean-Claude Trichet’s role as president of the European Central Bank ends, he will leave behind a more prominent institution and a difficult legacy for his successor.
articles.abstract: When Jean-Claude Trichet’s role as president of the European Central Bank ends, he will leave behind a more prominent institution and a difficult legacy for his successor.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Since Europe’s debt crisis became acute last year, the European Central Bank has gone beyond its role as arbiter of monetary policy to become in effect the adult supervision for quarreling heads of government.
